Selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a key reaction in biopolymer production. A non-noble metal catalyst and mild reaction conditions are highlighted in this work. Co-Cu nanoparticles supported on activated carbon (Co-Cu/AC) were introduced in the liquid-phase oxidation of HMF. The catalysts were prepared via a co-impregnation method, followed by reduction with hydrazine. The presence of the Cu promoter resulted in dispersion of the metal particles. The good distribution and small crystal size of Co3O4 significantly increased the active surface area and enhanced the catalytic activity. In addition, the presence of CuO synergized with the oxidation ability of the Co catalyst to increase the FDCA yield. The catalytic activity at different reaction temperatures, reaction times, catalyst loadings, and Co:Cu ratios revealed that the highest selectivity for FDCA (92%) was achieved using the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst. According to the proposed reaction mechanism, the redox reaction between Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Co4+, together with H2O2 as the oxidant, promotes the complete oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Co-Cu catalyst Selective oxidation Biopolymer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, biomass-based chemicals have received increasing attention owing to their sustainability and renewability, which has reduced global environmental pollution. Polyethylenefuranoate (PEF) is an important biomass-derived polymer that can replace polyethylene terephthalate. PEF is synthesized via the condensation polymerization of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which is derived from the selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and ethylene glycol [1]. In the selective oxidation of HMF, the catalyst plays a key role in promoting the reaction pathway toward FDCA formation. Various oxidation catalysts have been developed for FDCA production, especially those using noble metals. For instance, Pd-Au and Au catalysts have been used for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA [2–5]. Xia et al. [6] studied the effectiveness of monometallic (Pd/HT and Au/HT) and bimetallic (Pd-Au/HT) catalysts supported on hydrotalcite (Mg-Al hydroxycarbonate, HT) for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The bimetallic catalyst exhibited a higher activity for the oxidation of HMF and afforded a 90% yield of FDCA under an O2 flow at 60°C after 6 h of reaction. Notably, a monometallic Pd catalyst did not afford an FDCA yield higher than 90%. Wan et al. proposed a four-step reaction mechanism for the aerobic oxidation of HMF, which consisted of the oxidation of HMF to 5-diformyl furan (DFF) and 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), oxidation of DFF to 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and oxidation of FFCA to FDCA. The reaction mainly proceeded via the pathway of HMF oxidation to DFF in the presence of a monometallic Pd catalyst. A Au catalyst promoted the oxidation of HMF to HMFCA; therefore, the presence of Au in a bimetallic Pd-Au catalyst synergized the oxidation of HMF to FDCA [7]. Pt nanoparticles on N-doped carbon showed good catalytic activity for the aerobic oxidation of HMF, achieving an 84% FDCA yield within 24 h of reaction at 110°C [8]. Pt/HZSM-5 and Pt/mesoporous NiO exhibited full conversion with FDCA selectivities of 80 and 100%, respectively [9,10]. A few studies have reported the two-step oxidation of HMF to HMFCA and FDCA; however, a high yield of HMFCA is desirable for the production of various products including 2,5-dimethylfuran, 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid, and FDCA. An Ag2O/CaCO3 catalyst can be used to achieve a high yield of HMFCA (93%) with a 95% HMF conversion [10]. Pd/AlPO4 was used for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions, affording an FDCA selectivity of 83.6% with a 38.8% HMF conversion at 80°C for 5 h [11]. According to the literature, noble metals are the main catalysts for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA, affording high efficiencies for both conversion and selectivity. The oxidation of HMF over a Ru/C catalyst in a biphasic H2O/dioxane system and base solution resulted in an FDCA yield of 98% [12]. A Au-based catalyst was used to achieve a rapid and complete conversion of HMF with an FDCA selectivity of 90% within 41 s [5]. Although noble metals exhibit excellent catalytic activity for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, cost competitiveness is a major issue for the commercial use of noble metal catalysts. Ultralow noble metal (Au, Pt, Pd)-encapsulated HZSM-5 and MCM-22 catalysts were developed to overcome this cost-competitiveness issue. A 90% FDCA yield with a 95% HMF conversion could be achieved at 60°C and 0.3 MPa [13]. Non-noble metals have been extensively studied to achieve efficiencies that are similar to those of noble metals. Fe nanoparticles were synthesized and used as catalysts for HMF oxidation. A complete HMF conversion over Fe nanoparticles under low O2 pressure was achieved, with an FDCA yield of 89.4% [14]. To improve the catalytic performance, bimetallic Co-based catalysts have been introduced. A Co-Ce mixed oxide catalyst was used for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The oxidation reaction can be performed via the coupling redox reactions of Ce4+/Ce3+ and Co3+/Co2+ to obtain an FDCA selectivity of 86.3% within 4 h [14]. Co-Nb magnetic nanoparticles as core-shell structures promote the decomposition of oxidizing agents and adsorption on the active sites, which improves the selectivity for FDCA formation [15]. Liquid-phase oxidation over a Co/Mn/Br catalyst was performed via a semi-continuous oxidation mechanism, resulting in an FDCA yield of 92% at 150°C and 0.8 MPa of O2 [1,16]. In addition to the Co-based catalysts, CuO has been introduced as a promoter to improve the oxidation efficiency. Cu-doped MnO has also been used for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, improving the synergistic effect of Cu2+ and MnO2 to achieve an FDCA yield of 96.8% [17]. The excellent catalytic performance was attributed to an improvement in the electronic structure and charge transfer via the Cu-Co heterostructure, affording an FDCA yield of 91% with a 100% HMF conversion [18]. Based on the synergistic effect of Cu2+ and MnO2, a Co-Cu bimetallic catalyst can promote a similar catalytic cycle, as proposed in Scheme 1 . In the catalytic cycle of Cu, Cu2+ is converted to Cu+, which then oxidizes HMF to DFF, FFCA, and FDCA. Moreover, metallic Cu has a high oxygen affinity, which makes it a good promoter when combined with active metals [19,20]. Cu can also act as a structural promoter to prevent the aggregation of active metals. Sheng et al. [21] developed a Co-Cu bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrogenation. The presence of Cu reduced the size of the Co clusters, which were then well dispersed. In this study, Co-Cu nanoparticles supported on activated carbon (Co-Cu/AC) were prepared. The catalytic activity for the liquid-phase oxidation of HMF to FDCA, using H2O2 as the oxidant, was investigated. The effects of reaction parameters, including temperature, reaction time, Co:Cu ratio, and catalyst loading, on HMF conversion and FDCA yield were evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Co-Cu/AC A series of Co-Cu/AC catalysts were synthesized via incipient wetness co-impregnation on activated carbon at a maximum total metal content of 20 wt.% of the catalyst. Different Co/Cu mass ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1) were prepared by mixing 40 mL of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O aqueous solutions in a round-bottom flask with vigorous stirring. Subsequently, activated carbon was slowly added to the precursor solution. Next, the slurry was stirred vigorously at 40°C for 4 h, after which the solution was dried at 80°C for 24 h and calcined at 500°C for 2 h to obtain the catalyst in the oxide form. 2.2 Characterization of the Co-Cu/AC catalysts The crystal phases of the Co-Cu/AC catalysts (metal oxide form) were investigated using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; D8 ADVANCE, Bruker) in the 2θ range of 5–80° with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA and a scan speed of 0.1 s per step. The morphology and elemental distribution of the fresh and spent Co-Cu/AC catalysts were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100) at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. The nitrogen sorption isotherm was obtained using an Autosorb iQ-C chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) to determine the surface area and porosity of the catalysts. The specific surface area was derived using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation and t-plot method, whereas the pore size and pore-size distribution were calculated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method. The reducibility of the catalysts was evaluated using hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on a BELCAT instrument (BEL Inc.). Prior to the analysis, 0.05 g of the catalyst was pretreated in a He flow at 400°C for 1 h and then cooled to 100°C. In all tests, the temperature was increased from 100 to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 in a He flow of 50 mL min−1. The surface chemical composition was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PHI 5000 VersaProbe II, ULVAC-PHI, Inc., Minnesota, USA) using Al Kα radiation. 2.3 Liquid-phase oxidation of HMF and product analysis The catalysts in the oxide form were reduced using hydrazine hydrate (N2H4OH) in a 20 mL glass bottle with a screw cap and a Thermo-mighty stirrer (Koike Precision Instruments, HHE-19G-US). Initially, 0.0050 g of the catalyst (oxide form) and two drops of hydrazine hydrate were added to the bottle. The mixture was heated at 95°C for 1 h and cooled to 40°C for the subsequent HMF oxidation. HMF oxidation was carried out in a 20 mL glass bottle reactor. First, HMF (0.0250 g) and Na2CO3 (0.0313 g) were dissolved in deionized water (9 mL) and transferred to the reactor. Next, H2O2 (2 mL) was added to the glass bottle when the mixture reached the desired reaction temperature and time. The product obtained was filtered to separate out the catalyst. For the reusability study, the spent catalyst was collected, washed several times with ethanol, and dried at 80°C. The reusability of the catalyst was determined using three methods: with and without calcination at 500 °C for 2 h and via regeneration with H2O2 [22,23]. Briefly, 1 g of spent 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst was immersed in 20 mL of 0.01 N H2O2 and vigorously stirred for 1.5 h. After chemical regeneration, the catalysts were dried at 105 °C for 2 h. Before being reused for the HMF oxidation reaction, the spent 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst was re-reduced with hydrazine hydrate at 95°C for 1 h. The effects of the reaction parameters, including reaction temperature (110, 130, 150, and 170°C), reaction time (3–9 h), and HMF/catalyst ratio (5, 10, and 15 wt.%), on the catalyst performance were investigated to achieve a high yield of the desired products. The HMF conversion and product yields were analyzed using a high-performance liquid chromatograph (Shimadzu LC-10ADvp-HPLC pump) coupled with a UV detector on an Eclipse Plus C18 column (250 × 4.6 mm), with aqueous acetonitrile (20% acetonitrile and 80% H2O) as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1 mL min−1 at 40°C. The volume of the injected sample was 25 µL. The HMF conversion and product yield were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively: (1) Conversion ( % ) = Mole of HMF reacted Mole of HMF added × 100 (2) Yield ( % ) = Mole of product obtained Mole of HMF added × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The textural properties of the Co-Cu/AC catalysts are shown in Fig. S1 and Table 1 . The activated carbon and Co-Cu/AC catalysts exhibited an IUPAC type-IV isotherm, which was attributed to their mesoporous structure. The sorption isotherms with different ratios of Co to Cu were not significantly different, indicating that the loading of the active metals was successful without pore blockage. As presented in Table 1, the total surface area slightly decreased from 461 to 419 m2 g−1 after metal loading; however, the surface area increased to 494 m2 g−1 owing to the formation of a hierarchical porous structure. The total pore volume slightly increased after metal loading, indicating the formation of a hierarchical porous structure and non-blockage of the porous structure. The pore diameters of the catalysts were in the range 3.0–3.8 nm. The pore-size distributions of the catalysts were wider than that of the activated carbon owing to the formation of new hierarchical pores (Fig. S1b). Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the Cu/AC, Co/AC, and Co-Cu/AC catalysts in the oxide form with different ratios of Co to Cu. Peaks attributed to the (311) and (400) diffraction planes of CoO can be distinctly observed at the 2θ values of 37° and 45°, respectively [24]. The CuO diffraction peaks at 35° and 49° correspond to the (111) and (202) diffraction planes. The intensity of the prominent CuO diffraction peak at 39° decreases with an increasing Co:Cu ratio. The presence of Cu (0) and Co (0) can also be observed owing to a partial carbothermal reduction of the metal oxides. The crystal size was calculated using the Scherrer formula, as presented in Table 1. The addition of Cu promoted the distribution of Co along the surface of the activated carbon, which decreased the crystal size of Co with an increase in the Co:Cu ratio. The crystal size of Co decreased from 99.3 to 54.7 nm when the Co:Cu ratio increased from 1:1 to 4:1. In contrast, the crystal size of Cu remained relatively the same. Therefore, CuO doping was employed to inhibit the crystal growth of Co3O4 during calcination [25]. The composition of the surface metals was investigated using XPS, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The wide-scan spectra clearly show the presence of C 1 s, O 1 s, Cu 2p, and Co 2p peaks. The peaks at the binding energies of 284, 286, and 288 eV in the C 1 s spectra were attributed to C=C, C–O, and C=O, respectively, on the surface of the support (Fig. 2b). In the O 1 s spectra, the peaks at 531 and 533 eV correspond to non-stoichiometric O in the Co structure and O in the lattice of CuO, respectively (Fig. 2c) [26,27]. The Cu 2p3/2 peak at 933.5 eV concurrently present with a weak satellite peak at 945 eV confirms the formation of Cu2+ in the form of CuO (Fig. 2d). Fig. 2e shows the mixed oxidation states of Co2+ and Co3+, which correlate with Co3O4 in the absence of a CoO crystal phase. The Co and Cu contents were determined using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, and the results are presented in Table S1. The bulk ratio of Co to Cu in the Co-Cu/AC catalysts was similar to the as-prepared ratio; however, 4Co-Cu/AC did not increase the Co:Cu ratio because of the impending maximum loading of the activated carbon. The H2-TPR profile of monometallic Cu/AC shows two different peaks for CuO reduction in the temperature range 230–300°C, corresponding to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu+ to Cu0, as shown in Fig. 3 f. Meanwhile, reduction peaks of Co3O4 to CoO can be observed in the temperature ranges 210–290°C and 330–435°C, which correspond to the reduction of CoO to Co0, as shown in Fig. 3e [28]. The H2-TPR profile of the Co-Cu/AC catalyst exhibits a combination of the reduction peaks of Cu2+ and Co3O4. In comparison to the monometallic catalysts, the reduction temperatures of the bimetallic catalysts are shifted to higher temperatures, which indicates an electronic interaction between Co and Cu. Meanwhile, at a high ratio of Co to Cu, there is an additional peak at a reduction temperature of 500°C, owing to the reduction of small clusters of Co [29]. Fig. 4 shows TEM micrographs of the Co-Cu/AC catalysts with different Co:Cu ratios. Agglomeration of metal clusters is observed in the catalysts because of sintering during calcination (Fig. 4a and b). The size of the metal clusters decreased with an increasing Co:Cu ratio, and the metal clusters were present inside the pores of the activated carbon. The TEM images of the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst exhibit the smallest metal clusters and a good distribution along the surface of the activated carbon (Fig. 4g and h). A small amount of Cu inhibited sintering during the calcination process, which agrees with the XRD results. 3.2 Catalytic activity for liquid-phase oxidation of HMF The catalytic activity of Co-Cu/AC was investigated in the liquid-phase oxidation of HMF for FDCA production. The reaction was performed under reflux. A reaction pathway is proposed in Scheme 2 , in which HMF is converted to two different intermediates, HMFCA and DFF, yielding FFCA and FDCA. The effect of the Co:Cu ratio was studied (Fig. 5 a). The conversion of HMF (96–100%), with or without the catalyst, was not significantly affected by the Co:Cu ratio. HMF can undergo several processes during thermal decomposition; however, the presence of a catalyst can direct the reaction pathway toward the desired product. The product yields, especially for HMFCA and FDCA, were improved because the catalyst promoted selectivity for HMFCA and FDCA. The HMFCA yield with the catalyst was two-fold higher than that obtained without the catalyst. A low FDCA yield was observed for all the Co-Cu/AC catalysts except 4Co-Cu/Ac, suggesting that a good distribution of metal clusters and small metal-cluster size enhanced the catalytic activity to promote the conversion of HMFCA to FDCA. The highest FDCA yield of 41% was observed for the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst. The catalytic activity of the monometallic Co catalysts afforded a high yield of HMFCA because the oxidation performance of Co could not overcome the formation of FFCA. The Co-catalyst promoted the oxidation pathway via the formation of DFF with nearly 60% selectivity; however, the co-catalyst could not further oxidize DFF to FFCA and FFCA to FDCA [30]. Similar to the catalytic performance of Cu-doped MnO2, Cu acted as a co-catalyst to synergize the oxidation efficiency of the co-catalyst toward the formation of FFCA and FDCA. Therefore, a small crystal size and good metal-cluster dispersion play an important role in producing the desired products, and Cu acts as a co-catalyst to improve the oxidation performance of the co-catalyst. The effect of reaction temperature was investigated within the range of 110–170°C in the presence of the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst for a reaction time of 5 h and a catalyst loading of 10 wt.% (Fig. 5b). It was revealed that HMF was completely converted (100% conversion) at all investigated temperatures. The FDCA yield increased with increasing reaction temperature, whereas the HMFCA yield decreased. The reaction pathway presented a rapid conversion of HMF to HMFCA (step 1), in which a high HMFCA yield was achieved at a low reaction temperature of 110°C. The slowest step involved the conversion of HMFCA to FFCA, which required a high temperature to oxidize FFCA to FDCA. The highest FDCA yield (59%) was obtained at 170°C. Fig. 5c shows the effects of the reaction time on the HMF conversion and product yields. A complete conversion of HMF was attained within 3 h; however, the FDCA yield (44%) was low. The FDCA yield increased from 44% to 92% when the reaction time was increased from 3 to 9 h. The subsequent reactions from HMFCA to FFCA and FFCA to FDCA may occur at long reaction times. Catalyst loading also had a significant effect on the FDCA yield, as shown in Fig. 5d. The HMF conversion was not significantly affected by the catalyst loading; however, the FDCA yield was highly dependent on the catalyst loading owing to the number of active sites. The yield of FDCA increased from 74% to 92% with an increase in the catalyst loading from 5 to 10 wt.%; however, the FDCA yield decreased to 51% at a catalyst loading of 15 wt.%. A decrease in FDCA yield at high catalyst loadings is generally caused by non-homogeneous mixing of solid catalysts in liquid reaction systems [15,31]. In this study, the optimum conditions were determined as follows: reaction temperature of 170°C, reaction time of 9 h, and 10 wt.% catalyst loading, which gave an FDCA yield of 92%. The reusability of the catalyst was determined using two methods: with and without calcination. The catalytic performance of 4Co-Cu/AC is shown in Fig. 6 . For the uncalcined catalyst, the FDCA yield rapidly decreased to 49% after the third cycle, whereas the HMFCA yield increased (Fig. 6a). The decrease in the FDCA yield was attributed to the deactivation of the active metal, which played a key role in promoting the oxidation of HMFCA to FDCA. The used catalyst was then regenerated via calcination at 500°C for 2 h, and its catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 6b. The calcined catalyst performed better than the uncalcined catalyst, showing only a 17% decrease in the FDCA yield after the third cycle. A non-thermal regeneration method was applied to prevent the agglomeration of metal clusters. The FDCA yield decreased by 7% after the second cycle, as shown in Fig. 6c. Based on TEM micrographs (Fig. 7 ), the catalyst morphology indicates deactivation of the catalyst. Agglomeration of the metal clusters was observed in the calcined catalyst because of sintering during the calcination process (Fig. 7c and d). The decrease in the FDCA yield over the calcined catalyst was attributed to the loss of active surface area owing to agglomeration. The TEM micrographs of the used catalyst show carbon deposition and fiber growth on the catalyst surface, which resulted in catalyst deactivation (Fig. 7e and f). Thermogravimetric profiles of the fresh Co-Cu/AC catalyst and used 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst after the third cycle clearly show 12 wt.% coke deposition, as shown in Fig. S2. From the catalyst reusability study, the catalyst could be partially recovered via calcination and reused for up to three cycles with a 17% decrease in the FDCA yield. The catalytic performance of the Co-Cu/AC catalyst was compared with those of other catalysts (Table 2 ). The FDCA yield over the Co-Cu/AC catalyst is lower than that over noble metal catalysts; however, the reaction was carried out under milder conditions. Compared with the non-noble metal Co-Mn catalyst, the Co-Cu/AC catalyst gave a higher FDCA yield or superior HMF conversion. As indicated by the experimental results, CuO not only hindered the agglomeration of the Co3O4 clusters but also acted as a co-catalyst to promote the oxidation reaction and enhance the catalytic activity via redox coupling between HMF and H2O2. Therefore, the Co-Cu/AC catalyst is an interesting non-noble metal catalyst that synergizes the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, achieving a high FDCA yield under mild conditions. This study also proposes a process for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild conditions in an environmentally friendly manner. The reaction can be carried out at atmospheric pressure without the formation of toxic compounds. This catalytic system has potential applications in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. 4 Conclusions A series of Co-Cu/AC catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness co-impregnation of Co(NO3)2 and Cu(NO3)2 on activated carbon with different Co:Cu ratios. The presence of Cu as a promoter played a key role in reducing the size and distribution of metal clusters along the surface of the activated carbon. The 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst had the smallest metal-cluster size and good metal-cluster distribution, as confirmed by XRD and TEM. The presence of Cu improved the FDCA yield, and the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst gave the highest yield of FDCA (92%) at a reaction temperature of 170°C, reaction time of 9 h, and catalyst loading of 10 wt.%. The 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst could be recycled via 2 h of calcination at 500°C for up to three cycles, with a 17% decrease in the FDCA yield. The catalytic performance of the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst was compared with those of noble and non-noble metal catalysts. The FDCA yield over the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst is lower than that over the noble metal catalysts; however, it can be achieved under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, the FDCA yield over the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst is higher than that over non-noble metal catalysts. Therefore, 4Co-Cu/AC is a promising catalyst for HMF oxidation because of its low operating cost and mild operating conditions. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a key reaction in biopolymer production. A non-noble metal catalyst and mild reaction conditions are highlighted in this work. Co-Cu nanoparticles supported on activated carbon (Co-Cu/AC) were introduced in the liquid-phase oxidation of HMF. The catalysts were prepared via a co-impregnation method, followed by reduction with hydrazine. The presence of the Cu promoter resulted in dispersion of the metal particles. The good distribution and small crystal size of Co3O4 significantly increased the active surface area and enhanced the catalytic activity. In addition, the presence of CuO synergized with the oxidation ability of the Co catalyst to increase the FDCA yield. The catalytic activity at different reaction temperatures, reaction times, catalyst loadings, and Co:Cu ratios revealed that the highest selectivity for FDCA (92%) was achieved using the 4Co-Cu/AC catalyst. According to the proposed reaction mechanism, the redox reaction between Cu2+/Cu+ and Co3+/Co4+, together with H2O2 as the oxidant, promotes the complete oxidation of HMF to FDCA.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient liquid-phase oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural over Co-Cu/activated carbon catalysts
